Award.AwardTitle: Many-Body Expansion of Direct and Mutual Polarization Models
Award.AbstractNarration:
Teresa Head-Gordon of the University of California, Berkeley is supported by an award from the Chemical Theory, Models and Computational Methods program in the Chemistry Division to develop computational and theoretical models and methods that can be used to make accurate predictions for the behavior of complex molecular systems. They are developing and testing the accuracy of several cost-effective approximate models. The goal is to understand when these approximate models are adequate and when more costly and accurate models are required. Professor Head-Gordon and her coworkers use their methods to study the properties and behavior of several important molecular and biomolecular systems including supercooled water, ionic liquids and proteins. Ionic liquids are more environmentally benign than traditional solvents used in industrial processes. For example, ionic liquids are able to dissolve biological plant materials so that they may be converted into renewable energy products. The Head-Gordon group also studies biological systems ranging from small peptides in water to the formation of protein-protein and protein-nucleic acid interactions. Such interactions are required for diverse biological processes such as signaling, regulation of gene expression, cell division, and DNA repair. An additional goal of this project is to foster opportunities for undergraduate research and to mentor women in the physical sciences.

The Head-Gordon research group has developed the Many-Body Expansion (MBE) of polarization to tackle the characterization of large condensed phase systems with a more accurate force field. In principle, mutually polarizable models offer a significant improvement in the physics of classical force fields. However, the corresponding increased computational cost renders statistical convergence of condensed phase observables more difficult to achieve. The researchers are analyzing the quality of the approximation to the MBE truncated at 3-bodies for four different polarizable models: iAMOEBA: an atomistic model that only accounts for direct polarization; AMOEBA: an atomistic point dipole model that accounts for mutual polarization; PB-SAM: a new semi-analytical solution to the linearized Poisson-Boltzmann equation (PBE) that accounts for complete mutual polarization; and iPB-SAM: devised to account for direct polarization only. The new atomistic-based polarizable models and algorithms provide a more sophisticated level of model physics for bulk water and ionic liquids as well as peptides and proteins. New PB-SAM formulations of the PBE allow simulation of the mechanism of complex formation and rate of association needed for understanding function in the crowded cellular environment, for example ~1000 proteins in E. coli cytoplasm or other complex materials such as Nafion. In addition it provides a practical guide to consumers of chemical software in the proper application of theoretical models, as to which statistical properties and mechanisms of condensed phase chemical systems actually require an advancement over a classical pairwise additive force field.

POR.DRECONTENT:
We have worked on moving the simulation field forward and away from the two-body approximation of molecular interactions to higher accuracy molecular mechanics forms that include many-body polarization; more specifically he worked on the AMOEBA (Atomic Multipole Optimized Energetics for Biomolecular Applications) model. However, the greater complexity of this additional many-body physics poses great challenges: rational and robust force field design since they are harder to parameterize, algorithmic challenges due to their cost, as well as software challenges to allow for necessary statistical mechanical sampling on multi-core architectures. We have worked on all three of these areas during the last three years- the complete scope of the problem - with impactful results.

My group has worked on new solutions to the SCF equations for polarization – one of the primary algorithmic bottlenecks of a many-body potential. The new method, iEL/SCF, dynamically integrates a set of auxiliary dipoles that serve as a time-reversible initial guess for the SCF solver for classical polarization. It improves energy conservation and reduces the number of SCF cycles by half – so that now the many-body cost is reduced closer to the cost of just the chosen level of pairwise permanent electrostatics – and thus breaking down one of the barriers of using the many-body potential as a replacement for the current force field standard. We have also extended this result to the exciting outcome of doing no SCF iterations for mutual polarization.

The second area we worked on was the recasting of the many-body polarization as a many-body expansion (MBE), allowing one to refactor the software for the polarization in terms of independent evaluation of one body, two body and three body interactions that can be trivially parallelized. This project led to deeper understanding that truncation of the MBE at 3rd order captures direct polarization exactly and yields an apparent good approximation to the mutual polarization energy which we call 3-AMOEBA. We showed that the MBE renders large errors in the magnitude of mutual polarization forces, and requires at least 4th order terms in the MBE to converge toward the parent potential gradient values. Although the MBE is used ubiquitously for energies in the quantum mechanical community – our study on classical potentials suggests that the QM community should more carefully investigate the convergence of forces. We then showed that one can improve the convergence of polarization forces for 3-AMOEBA by embedding the polarization response of dimers and trimers within a complete representation of the fixed electrostatics of the entire system. 

Finally, the design challenge is manifested in the fact that existing polarizable force fields are proving surprisingly brittle in some applications. In the case of blind prediction in the Statistical Assessment of the Modeling of Proteins and Ligands (SAMPL) exercises, it has been shown that the two-body models are often as or more accurate for hydration free energies and guest-host ligand binding than are the more sophisticated polarizable counterparts. One way forward on the design challenge is to develop force field terms that match the intrinsic contributions to first principles quantum mechanical (QM) interaction energies. We have connected the classical polarizable model to a basic chemical system – an ion and water interaction – via a variational energy decomposition analysis (EDA). It reveals the imperfections of these advanced force fields – at a minimum they should at least realize a cancellation of error – but they neither do this nor by extension get the individual decompositions right.
